channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Church Confronts Abuse Scandal at a Famed German Choir
item.description: A scandal that, because of the choir’s association with the former pope’s brother, became one of the most troublesome to roil the Vatican in the last decade and more.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Udo Kaiser was 8 years old when he joined the Regensburg Domspatzen choir.

item.title: Rescue Efforts Continue as Toll Rises in Taiwan Earthquake
item.description: At least 13 people were killed in the quake in Tainan, officials said, mainly in a 17-story apartment building that collapsed, but most of the city seemed to be unscathed.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Rescue workers searched the rubble of a collapsed building in Tainan, Taiwan, on Saturday after a 6.4-magnitude earthquake.

item.title: Kunduz Residents Live in Fear of Taliban’s Return
item.description: Four months after the Taliban overtook Kunduz for two weeks, Afghan forces remain overstretched, and residents worry that the return of the insurgents is inevitable.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM, DAVID JOLLY and AHMAD SHAKIB
item.media:description: Afghan forces at the airport as they fought in October to take back Kunduz City from insurgents.

item.title: North Korea Launches Rocket Seen as Cover for a Missile Test
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have condemned the plan, while North Korea proceeded on Sunday in defiance of warnings.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: El Salvador Arrests Ex-Military Officers in 1989 Jesuit Killings
item.description: Officials said they would continue raids that have so far netted four of the 16 men being sought in connection with the murders of six priests and two others.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Released From Guantánamo, but in Legal Limbo in Morocco
item.description: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and AIDA ALAMI
item.media:description: Thirty-four of the 91 remaining detainees at the Guantánamo prison have been recommended for transfer.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Zhang Hui and Bu Haixia
item.description: Two zookeepers, Zhang Hui and Bu Haixia, discussed their monkeys, what’s different about the Year of the Monkey and whether the monkeys care about it.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Monkeys relaxing by a pond at the Nanjing Hongshan Forest Zoo.

item.title: Priest Abuse Victim Is Suspended From Vatican Panel
item.description: A high-profile Vatican commission on the prevention of child sexual abuse voted on Saturday to temporarily suspend one of its members.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Peter Saunders was on a 17-member commission created to address sexual abuse.

item.title: How a Medical Mystery in Brazil Led Doctors to Zika
item.description: A sudden, sharp increase in babies with “no foreheads and very strange heads” was baffling doctors in Brazil. That set off a search for answers that led to a little-known pathogen, the Zika virus.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr., SIMON ROMERO and SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: An Aedes aegypti female mosquito on water inside a tire at a used tire store in Villavicencio, Colombia. The mosquito carries the Zika virus, and females leave their eggs on damp surfaces.

item.title: Iranian Commander Dismisses Saudi Role in Syria
item.description: Maj. Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, the leader of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps, ridiculed the notion of Saudi Arabia’s intervening in the Syrian civil war, saying the kingdom lacked “the courage to do it.”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Walid al-Moallem of Syria said Saturday any intervention would be aggression.

item.title: Iran Panel Reverses Disqualification of Election Candidates
item.description: Iran’s reformist faction has tried to flood the vetting committee, known as the Guardian Council, with candidates, hoping that enough would slip through for their faction to win a majority in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: News Analysis: Pakistan’s Hand in the Rise of International Jihad
item.description: Sunni extremists are being recruited and trained to fight in conflicts abroad.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: The funeral of Saeed Jawad Hossini, 29, who was killed in a Taliban suicide attack in Kabul in January.

item.title: 2 Radio Journalists Attacked by Gunmen in Afghanistan
item.description: The attack on two brothers in Baghlan Province, which left one of them in a coma, was the latest in a series of assaults on members of the Afghan news media.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Wanted in China: More Male Teachers, to Make Boys Men
item.description: Education officials across China are aggressively recruiting male teachers, as the Chinese news media warn of a need to “salvage masculinity in schools.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lin Wei is a sixth-grade teacher at a primary school in Fuzhou, China. Chinese educators are worried that a shortage of male teachers has produced a generation of timid, self-centered students.

item.title: Videos Made by Civilians Fleeing Aleppo Show Scenes of Devastation
item.description: One video showed what it said were the first moments after a Russian airstrike , while another showed cars lined up on the road to a Turkish border crossing.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Taiwan Mobilizes Army to Search Rubble After Earthquake
item.description: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck southern Taiwan, leveling at least one residential building and trapping dozens of people.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: Rescue workers at damaged buildings in Tainan, Taiwan, on Saturday. The epicenter of the 6.4-magnitude earthquake was about 30 miles southeast of Tainan.

item.title: U.S. Judge Approves Extradition of Former Salvadoran Colonel
item.description: The ex-colonel, accused in the 1989 murder of six Jesuit priests, a housekeeper and her teenage daughter in El Salvador, was ordered deported.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Ukrainian Ex-Premier’s Visit to Washington Highlights Obstacles Facing Peace Pact
item.description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko said she would staunchly oppose constitutional changes that the United States and European powers view as crucial to a peace agreement with Russia.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, a former prime minister of Ukraine, before the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday in Washington.

item.title: Argentina Reaches Debt Deal With 2 Hedge Funds
item.description: Montreux Partners and Dart Management have agreed to take an offer made by the South American nation.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Quake Fells Taiwan Apartment Building, at Least Two Dead
item.description: A powerful earthquake toppled a 17-story apartment building in southern Taiwan on Saturday, killing at least two people, including a 10-day-old girl, and triggering frantic efforts to rescue dozens of people feared trapped inside.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Rescue workers at an office building that collapsed in Tainan, in southern Taiwan.
